facts.text: Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Act 21 of 1947) received assent of Governor-General on May 23, 1947 and came into force on June 1, 1947.
Notification No. 601 issued on May 27, 1947 publishing draft rules under s.28 of the Act.
Rules finally adopted published on August 15, 1947.
Notification No. 597 issued on May 27, 1947 under s.8 fixing August 15, 1947 as date by which dealers liable to pay tax shall get registered.
Notification No. 599 issued on May 27, 1947 under s.3 appointing District Excise Officers as Sales Tax Officers for receiving applications for registration and issuing certificates under s.8.
Notification No. 595 dated May 27, 1947 appointing Excise Commissioner as Commissioner of Sales Tax under s.3(1).
Appellant, a company manufacturing and selling potteries chinaware in Nagpur, presented application for registration on July 2, 1947 pursuant to notifications.
Registration certificate issued to appellant on July 21, 1947 and delivered on September 13, 1947.
Appellant submitted returns and paid taxes for period June 1, 1947 to June 30, 1951.
Appellant instituted suit on December 18, 1951 claiming refund of Rs. 6,650-11-9 paid as sales tax from June 1, 1947 to June 30, 1951 and Rs. 2,000 as damages.
Civil Judge of Nagpur dismissed suit holding irregularity in registration cured by delivery after rules published and liability not affected by invalid registration.
Appeal to Bombay High Court (Circuit Bench at Nagpur, F.A. No. 32 of 1955) dismissed, certificate under s.109 CPC and Art.132 Constitution granted.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant is liable to pay tax under the Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 on the ground that it had not been validly registered as a dealer under s.8 of the Act.

Whether Notification No. 599 dated May 27, 1947 appointing District Excise Officers as Sales Tax Officers contravened s.3(1) as 'prescribed' designations required rules not in force until August 15, 1947.
Whether invalid registration affects liability to tax under s.4 and validity of assessments.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sales Tax Officer who issued registration certificate on July 21, 1947 was not authorised under the Act as per s.3(1), since 'prescribed' designations mean by rules under s.2(e), rules final only on August 15, 1947; thus all assessments and recoveries illegal and void.
Procedure for assessment differs for unregistered dealers requiring notice under s.10(1) and Rule 22; no such notice issued, so assessments incompetent if registration invalid.

respondent_arguments.text: Liability to pay tax arises under s.4 (charging section) independent of registration under s.8.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correct that appellant liable to pay tax under Act irrespective of whether registration under s.8 valid or not; liability arises under s.4(1)(a), not conditional on registration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section 8(1) prohibits unregistered dealer from carrying business but does not affect substantive liability under s.4.

court_reasoning.text: Position of dealer with invalid registration same as one who failed to register; neither absolved from tax liability under s.4.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dealer failing registration hit by s.8(1), may lose s.11(1) benefit, but not better position than registered dealer.

court_reasoning.text: Jurisdiction to assess under ss.3 and 11, not s.10 which is procedural; appellant submitted voluntary returns under s.10(1), cannot contend proceedings without jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between want of jurisdiction (nullity, collateral attack) and irregular assumption (not nullity, no collateral attack); proceedings on voluntary returns valid.

court_reasoning.text: Even for unregistered dealer, failure to issue notice under s.10(1) mere irregularity, assessment not without jurisdiction; a fortiori when appellant submitted returns.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.21 bars civil court jurisdiction to question orders under Act.

holdings.text: Appellant liable to pay tax under s.4 irrespective of validity of registration under s.8; invalid registration has no effect on validity of assessment proceedings.
Assessments based on voluntary returns by appellant are valid; no collateral attack possible on procedural irregularities.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Act 21 of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs tax liability (s.4 charging), registration requirement (s.8 prohibitory not absolving), assessment procedure (ss.10,11), appointments (s.3), bar on civil suits (s.21)

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal involving substantial question of law

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal agreeing with High Court that appellant liable to sales tax under s.4 irrespective of registration validity under s.8; assessments on voluntary returns valid; suit for refund dismissed.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs (as per lower courts)

key_quotes.text: the High Court is clearly correct in its view that the appellant was liable to pay the tax under the Act irrespective of whether the registration under s. 8 was valid or not.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on independence of tax liability from registration

key_quotes.text: there is a fundamental distinction between want of jurisdiction and irregular assumption of jurisdiction
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why assessments valid despite procedural issues

key_quotes.text: The position of the dealer who has obtained a certificate of registration which turns out to be invalid cannot on principle, be distinguish[ed] from that of one who has failed to obtain a certificate.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects petitioner's distinction based on registration status
